content: Thread for today's meeting.

Hello everyone,

It's time for the @WG-governance meeting! React/Reply with :wave: to indicate your attendance.
I noticed today that project group RFC was not yet merged
I will merge it now...
/me !@#! hates merging RFCs
we should write some tooling for this :)
s/we/someone else/ :P
I don't believe we have any agenda set today, though I'll admit I haven't been the best at keeping one since covid.
Heh, I have a few things to bring up
we do, one sec
Aha, I can add the things Niko has to the agenda doc then
maybe they're already there
https://hackmd.io/ATj1rZJaRimaIfIWfAOYfQ?edit

Pasting here

  • Continue fleshing out definition of WG
  • Proposed:
    -- Domain WG retrospective
    -- Discussion of visibility of resources
    -- Effective discussion of contested RFCs
I updated it back when I did the minutes and the blog post (and found the other blog post I had committed but not PRed)
If what you had was not there, It can be added to the agenda and the other things deferred of course
gotta log into Hackmd
mostly it's there, but there are a few minor notes
more "announcements"
First off, I wanted to mention that once I merge rfc#2856 we should move that content to forge
that is, the definition of a project group, and notes on how they operate
so we can link to it :)
cool
Ok, I'm on vacation from today until the 2nd, so I can do that (:
I can take that.
@Val Grimm All yours

but secondly, and perhaps more importantly, we had a lang team "design meeting" last week about our procedures and proposals. I'll be posting a transcript + recording soon, but in the meantime I've started a draft of the RFC.
The recording is already up no? Or was this another meeting?
oh, maybe I already posted it
but not the transcript
I was just watching the proposal meeting today. :slight_smile:
someone is still working on a tool to convert from a VTT file to something readable
well, more readable than the raw format, anyway
comments on the draft above are probably best placed in #t-lang > Design meeting: procedures
anyway, that's all
A question I had listening to to the meeting, is this different than the compiler's major change process, and if so how?
re: domain working groups, I think @Val Grimm and I drafted some communication, though I at least didn't send or post anything

XAMPPRocky said:

A question I had listening to to the meeting, is this different than the compiler's major change process, and if so how?

they're similar and in fact I think could be "coallesced"

(I was going to bring that up. I just sent it. facepalm I waited too long for more comments and then hit a time problem from getting ready for vacation/wedding, so that's on me. I'll do better in general with this stuff now that I'm not overloaded with a few more work things than made sense. )
there are some specifics that are different in the t-lang variant, and I think I'd probably change the compiler team variant to match
but the main difference is that the compiler almost always ends in "we make PRs" whereas the lang-team almost always ends in "we make a group and write RFCs"
still, I think they have the same basic shape
I am very curious if we can consolidate this concept into something that works across teams
since e.g. the libs team currently doesn't really use RFCs, but maybe something like this for "API additions" would be sufficiently lightweight (similar to how compiler team MCPs)
Well, there's discussion and then an output seems to be the common element?
So what if the big picture model would be discussion and an output with examples of relevant outputs as given here?
Yeah that's what I'd like, from observing I really like the high level of "the team's repo contains the proposals, and goals of the team".

the big changes from today I think are:

  • you don't have to have everything figured out, you start more from motivation+problem (at least for lang)
  • we only one require one person on team to say "yes!" vs everyone signs off
  • we also do some "resourcing" -- i.e., we track who in team is working on what and you shouldn't be doing too many things at once
that last part isn't explicitly in the compiler team's process, but it's supposed to be

the other thing the lang team added is

  • after some amount of time, we automatically merge the proposal into a "Draft proposals", so things are kept tidy
(and we have it for reference later)
In compiler and libs does one person need to say yes? I had the sense it was maybe more people? Is that codified?
I did spend some time on the motivations, in particular I think separating out an RFC that is "likely to go forward" from "Early stage discussion on motivation and design space" is important

Val Grimm said:

In compiler and libs does one person need to say yes? I had the sense it was maybe more people? Is that codified?

so in all these cases, when the one person says "yes", it's not really a final decision
they're kind of saying "I will help", more than yes
so e.g. in lang team, let's say you find a liaison, they help you to craft an RFC, the RFC must still be accepted
similarly in compiler team, if you make a PR, the PR must still be reviewed (and if it makes user visible changes, it requires an rfcbot fcp)
though I think for compiler team it's really less important, these sorts of votes tend to be .. rare-ish
/me didn't mean to derail the meeting :)
Well I was just about to ask, we can continue discussing this and maybe what a team agnostic proposal looks like or we could move to another topic?
I guess -- re: domain WG follow-up -- I will send the e-mail I drafted up
or rather
I will post it on the github issues, and whatever internal threads there are

XAMPPRocky said:

Well I was just about to ask, we can continue discussing this and maybe what a team agnostic proposal looks like or we could move to another topic?

I'm ok either way, but at this point maybe it makes sense to stay on the topic. :) I have a few thoughts and doubts I could air and hear what people think.
Please, go ahead. :slight_smile:
One concern I have is that so many things are kind of cross-cutting
(domain WG the survey email to the leads at least is sent, I just sent it before this meeting)
So having per-team repos maybe "silos" the conversation in ways that could prevent us from getting feedback we want
I guess even if they're not cross-cutting
I think I'm mainly thinking that sometimes the decision to pursue something is one worth talking about
and I worry a bit about how to bring that conversation about
one thought I've had in the past is that chartering a project group ought to be an RFC
That might be ok for the initial process - it ensures that, while it is being formed, the feedback is coming from people with context
and I think that this may be appropriate, though it's not always worked out as well as I'd like
yes, I'm also wondering if I worry too much :)
The conversation about a specific proposal, prior to the "liaison says yes" threshold?
I guess maybe this is it. I feel like I want two contradictory things.
I feel like, as a team, we should encourage each other to pursue things that seem important to us -- so e.g. having someone feel it's important should be enough to at least kind of start exploration
But I also think we need to have group discussions
Maybe part of the responsibility of the liaison could be to help determine which other teams might want to have input on a topic and invite them to participate or at least give feedback?
@nikomatsakis I'm assuming this in a situation where not all of the members are in agreement around the topic?

one way to square that circle is to say something like, first, we will discuss in meetings etc before becoming liaison, so we'll uncover some objections, and perhaps to say that one route is to say "that seems like a big decision, you should create a zulip stream but the first task is to draw up a charter"

i.e., if you think of staging, there is kind of

  • Proposal
  • Writing charter
  • Writing/implementing RFC

and sometimes the proposal/charter are kind of done in one step, and sometimes they're not
@BatmanAoD (Kyle Strand) I think I agree with that, though I think it'd be good if we made it kind of part of the "charter" or something to list stakeholders who ought to be consulted?
( anyway, I also sort of suspect this is something we can iterate on, which is why I'm trying not to let it stop me, because I think we have to do something and we'll see how it goes )
in some way, these doubts I guess have more to do with the "project group" process than the "proposal" part of it :)
What are your strongest doubts about the project group part of the process, in this context?

So:

  • liaisons can volunteer, but can't actually be "assigned" until there's been a brief opportunity for all members of the relevant team to object in some way
  • objections can either be of the form "we shouldn't let this move forward at all" or "this effort needs an actual project group around it"
(deleted)

BatmanAoD (Kyle Strand) said:

can't actually be "assigned" until

I think I'd probably say it like you said more initially -- one of the jobs of a liaison is to make sure that lang-team members are on board
the easiest way to do that being bring it up in a meeting
not necessarily 100% on board to start of course
but there should be some point where we decide whether or not to do it

nikomatsakis said:

i.e., if you think of staging, there is kind of

  • Proposal
  • Writing charter
  • Writing/implementing RFC

and sometimes the proposal/charter are kind of done in one step, and sometimes they're not

That's true, though I'm unsure how to address that, I believe proposals try to be exhaustive because they want to be seriously considered, and to give the impression that the person proposing really did research.
and after that point, I think lang team members probably have to commit to supporting the idea :)
@XAMPPRocky maybe good to work through some examples
Oh, I meant the liaison would help determine whether/how _other_ teams need to weigh in.
I know, I extended it :)

i.e., step 1 is intra team, but step 2 is more about "who else out there" -- I don't think it's really about other teams necessarily, though that may be true, but just "key folks who should be consulted". e.g., for ffi-unwind that included @acfoltzer

I'm thinking of some interesting examples:

  • safe-transmute comes to mind
where we kind of have a strong motivation, and some pre-discussion, but the solution itself is evolving a lot
Well I have an example of an idea where I am unsure how to to go about it.
https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/bring-enum-variants-in-scope-for-patterns/12104/27?u=xampprocky

Ah, okay. So it's:

  • team liaison volunteers
  • liaison solicits initial (minimal) feedback from the "original" team
  • if the team doesn't outright veto the idea, liaison solicits feedback from other relevant teams, when appropriate

XAMPPRocky said:

https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/bring-enum-variants-in-scope-for-patterns/12104/27?u=xampprocky

your message (And Josh's reply) feels like precisely what the "proposals process" is meant to encourage and formalize
I also think that this is an example of something where the "proposal" could already include a lot of the solution, though it might be nice to list out alternatives and your preferred one
Yeah, to talk about the proposal, one of the reasons I haven't written anything yet, is because I don't know how much work I need to put into the initial proposal.
Like how exhaustive would one need to be about anonymous enums?
this would be good to clarify somehow
my hope is that the bar for proposals is fairly low
like, kind of the "elevator pitch"
enough to communicate the essentials of the idea
but I guess it will depend on the proposal too?

I'm trying to think, but I imagine that if you're offering up a proposal that is kind of a "ergonomic addition" (like _::) it would be enough to start with something simple. Maybe it wouldn't get accepted because "we don't hve the abndwidth to figure out if this can work, maybe talk to petrochenkov ..."

I guess actually that I think the thinsg that require more up-front work -- in a way -- require less? I'm thinking of things like async/await or unsafe-code-guidelines or what have you, where it feels like the details are too big to even really fit in a single RFC, and it's more about making the case for why this part of work is important

nikomatsakis said:

like, kind of the "elevator pitch"

Even for larger proposals I think it'd be good to say, you need to have an elevator pitch for it.
Proposals should ideally be compelling.
I think you have to be show the "rough shape" of a solution, enough to know it is solveable
Yeah, "Solve the turing problem" would be compelling but not feasible.
like I think with async-await there's enough precedent that you can kind of hearken to that
I'm trying to think of some other proposals and how they'd fit
another example: there have been a lot of proposals aiming to address this pattern

fn fo() {
    let x = match bar {
        Some(v) => v,
        None => ... return
    };
}

e.g., via something like

let Some(x) = match bar else return

or...someting...
I figure the actual syntax :)
but there are other ideas too of how one might address that

I feel like starting out with "we want to make this pattern less annoying, and here is one thing" might be good, but I'd like to see some exploration before we settle, but that could take place in a project group? at least that seems ideal to me
but maybe it already took place on internals and can just be listed ..
Maybe it would good to say something like, "Your proposal should contain at least one potential solution, but the team may require alternative proposed solutions before accepting"
Quick time check: We're at 10 minutes.
Yeah, I mean, I guess I don't think we'd require alternative proposals --
but it's definitely happened that RFCs come in with one solution in mind and get adapted
and/or that there are competing ideas for how to solve something, and in those cases, it'd be nice to get a summary of the ideas
I want to ask what do we want the output of this discussion around the proposals to be?
I think my ideal -- maybe unachievable :) -- is that we able to get people to give up a bit "ownership" of "my idea" vs "Nancy's idea" and more like "here are the ideas we as a group came up with"
so I would imagine we can accept a proposal with the intent of "first spend some time fleshing out the idea and thinking about possible alternatives"
(I feel like this is exactly what's happening with safe-transmute, for example)
100% that, I think removing ego and self is often one of the hardest things, but we should still work towards it.
We can at least require that any documents for public consumption (such as RFCs) produced by a project-group not use such terminology
...though probably in RFCs that's already not really a problem?

BatmanAoD (Kyle Strand) said:

We can at least require that any documents for public consumption (such as RFCs) produced by a project-group not use such terminology

Tangentially to that I wish there was a style/content guide for writing RFCs.
(I also think that the ffi-unwind WG was shooting for this, @BatmanAoD (Kyle Strand))
though we did also sort of take sides, but we tried to work together to elaborate the range of possibilities at least
before doing so :P
which seems good
so..4 minutes... I guess we don't have a lot of action items out of this meeting
though it was helpful for working through ideas
do we have thoughts on next week's agenda etc?
Well hopefully we get some replies to @Val Grimm's email, and should be able to discuss that.
I'll make notes from this
Sounds like the action items are to
Get the project defs into forge
and try to codify
a process like this that works for multiple groups, e.g. lang, compiler, libs?
(this as in what was discussed above)
keyboard oops, deleted
I'm thinking it's best to start with lang team before trying to "generalize"
but I do think that the "mirror shape" of MCP / Lang-team proposals is interesting
and maybe we should (e.g.) adopt the MCP terminology
lang-team "MCPs"
(please yes :slight_smile: )
I also plan to try and adapt the compiler-team to using PRs instead of issues
so that they have fewer "shallow differences"
(plus I think it'd be nice to be able to "merge" a proposal when it's accepted, etc)
Okay everyone that concludes the meeting for today, thank you for coming and stay safe!
Thank you for leading, @XAMPPRocky!
